prior_works.title: Information-Based Complexity
prior_works.authors: Joseph F. Traub, Grzegorz W. Wasilkowski, Henryk Woźniakowski
prior_works.role: Foundational theory of minimax optimal recovery via radius of information
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The paper’s core characterization—optimal reconstruction error equals the Chebyshev radius of the information-consistent set—directly instantiates the IBC principle that minimax error is the radius of information and the optimal algorithm is a center of that set.

prior_works.title: Optimal Recovery
prior_works.authors: Charles A. Micchelli, Timothy J. Rivlin
prior_works.role: Methodological precedent linking Chebyshev centers to worst-case estimation
prior_works.relationship_sentence: This work formalizes optimal recovery from bounded-error observations and shows that the Chebyshev center attains minimax error equal to the set’s radius, the exact geometric idea leveraged for approximate distance queries in general metric spaces.

prior_works.title: Optimal Estimation Theory for Bounded-Error Models (Set-Membership Identification)
prior_works.role: Set-membership estimation using Chebyshev centers under bounded noise
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Set-membership identification establishes that with bounded noise the feasible set of states should be summarized by its Chebyshev center for minimax accuracy, directly mirroring the paper’s reconstruction-from-annuli viewpoint and error characterization.

prior_works.title: Twenty Questions with Noise: Bayes Optimal Strategies
prior_works.authors: B. Jedynak, P. Frazier, R. Sisson
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provides the active learning and target localization framing for recovering an unknown point via noisy queries, which the paper generalizes to metric distance queries while giving tight worst-case (rather than Bayesian) guarantees.

prior_works.title: The Geometry of Generalized Binary Search
prior_works.role: Learning-theoretic framework tying query design to geometric structure
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Connects query efficiency and error to geometric/metric properties, informing the paper’s learning-theoretic lens and its translation of query outcomes into geometric feasible sets characterized by Chebyshev radius.

prior_works.title: On the Metric Dimension of a Graph
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Introduces landmark-based localization from distance information, a discrete analogue that motivates reconstructing a point from distances and highlights how metric geometry governs identifiability and error.

prior_works.title: Revealing Information while Preserving Privacy
prior_works.role: Privacy-reconstruction tradeoffs under noisy query access
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Shows that insufficient noise permits reconstruction from query answers, underpinning the paper’s secrecy viewpoint and motivating tight characterizations of how approximate distance answers leak location information.

synthesis_narrative:
The paper’s key contribution—a tight geometric characterization of optimal reconstruction error from approximate distance queries via the Chebyshev radius—sits squarely on the optimal recovery and information-based complexity traditions. Micchelli–Rivlin and the IBC monograph established that, for bounded-noise observations, the minimax error equals the radius of the information-consistent set and is achieved by its Chebyshev center. Milanese–Vicino’s set-membership estimation imported this principle into systems identification, operationalizing Chebyshev centers for bounded-error data. The present work extends and unifies these ideas to the query-driven setting over general (totally bounded) metric spaces, turning distance responses into geometric feasible sets (intersections of annuli/balls) and proving that their Chebyshev radius precisely captures optimal error.

On the querying side, noisy “twenty questions” (Jedynak–Frazier–Sisson) and generalized binary search (Nowak) framed target localization and active query design in a learning-theoretic language, highlighting how geometry governs rates. This paper complements those by providing worst-case, metric-space–agnostic guarantees and explicit formulas for Euclidean subsets, rather than Bayesian or discrete hypothesis settings. Finally, the secrecy angle echoes Dinur–Nissim’s reconstruction attacks: approximate answers can leak enough structure to localize targets unless noise is calibrated. The metric-dimension line (Harary–Melter) supplies a combinatorial precursor, showing that distances to landmarks can determine location; here, that intuition is elevated to a continuous, minimax-optimal characterization via the Chebyshev radius.
